qas.question: When did translation of material into Arabic begin to increase?
What allowed the expansion of Arabic translations during the 5th century?
What material was initial Arab translations primarily focused on?
What cultures' classical works were later translated into Arabic?
What type of translation drew heavily on earlier Near Eastern traditions?
When did translation of material into Arabic begin to stop?
What allowed the reduction of Arabic translations during the 5th century?
What material was initial Arab translations rarely focused on?
What cultures' classical works were never translated into Arabic?
What type of translation had no influence from earlier Near Eastern traditions?

context: Translation of material into Arabic expanded after the <a1_0><b6_0>creation of Arabic script<b6_0/><a1_0/> in the <a0_0><b5_0>5th century<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and gained great importance with the rise of Islam and Islamic empires. Arab translation initially focused primarily on <a2_0><b7_0>politics<b7_0/><a2_0/>, rendering Persian, Greek, even Chinese and Indic diplomatic materials into Arabic. It later focused on translating classical <a3_0><b8_0>Greek and Persian<b8_0/><a3_0/> works, as well as some Chinese and Indian texts, into Arabic for scholarly study at major Islamic learning centers, such as the Al-Karaouine (Fes, Morocco), Al-Azhar (Cairo, Egypt), and the Al-Nizamiyya of Baghdad. In terms of theory, <a4_0><b9_0>Arabic<b9_0/><a4_0/> translation drew heavily on earlier Near Eastern traditions as well as more contemporary Greek and Persian traditions.
